awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Broadening Participation of Underrepresented Groups in Civil Social Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
It has been scientifically well-documented that civil social institutions are most effective and durable when they are fully inclusive of the broader populations that they represent. This project explores what factors contribute to and inhibit the participation of underrepresented groups in civil society by looking at specific experiments that governments have used to increase participation. While training a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project would broadly disseminate its findings to organizations invested in discovering more effective methods for communicating science to the public. The findings of this research will be disseminated in such a way to aid researchers and policy-makers to improve policies and programming aimed at increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in civil society. The project also contributes to broadening the participation of individuals traditionally underrepresented in science.

Miriam Kilimo, under the supervision of Dr. Peter Little of Emory University will explore what impact government programs to engineer women's participation in civil society have on social relations. To address the low numbers of women in politics, numerous countries have adopted gender quotas in political representation. The gender quotas include methods such as requiring political parties to field female candidates during elections or to nominate them directly into political office. Although much research has been conducted to investigate which gender quotas work best to increase the number of women in political office, we still do not fully understand how these women experience the gender quota system. This research will be carried out in Kenya, where a 2010 constitution introduced gender quotas to increase women's political representation. Kenya's gender quota directs that women should occupy at least one-third of the seats in the 47 county assemblies. The gender quota has been implemented in two election cycles since 2010. When few women won seats by election, political parties nominated hundreds of women to county assemblies to meet the gender quota. However, these women have been criticized as allies of political parties that are dominated by men. Through observational methods, interviews, and document and media analyses, the researcher will investigate the experiences of female members of county assembly in Murang'a and Kwale counties in Kenya. These two counties have different ethnic groups, religions, and political histories. The study will address how female members of county assemblies participate in the county assembly and in the community, and how they relate to male members of county assemblies. The research will also examine the ideas about female members of county assemblies that are circulated in the public. The findings from the research will provide insight into how gender quotas shape political systems and the experiences of women who occupy political office.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored what impact government programs to engineer women's participation in civil society have on social relations. To address the low numbers of women in politics, numerous countries have adopted gender quotas in political representation. The gender quotas include methods such as requiring political parties to field female candidates during elections or to nominate them directly into political office. Although much research has been conducted to investigate which gender quotas work best to increase the number of women in political office, we still do not fully understand how these women experience the gender quota system.

This research was carried out in Kenya, where a 2010 constitution introduced gender quotas to increase women's political representation. Kenya's gender quota directs that women should occupy at least one-third of the seats in the 47 county assemblies. The gender quota has been implemented in two election cycles since 2010. When few women won seats by election, political parties nominated hundreds of women to county assemblies to meet the gender quota. However, these women have been criticized as allies of political parties that are dominated by men. Through observational methods, interviews, and document and media analyses, the researcher investigated the experiences of female members of county assembly (MCAs) in Murang'a and Kwale counties in Kenya. The study addressed how female members of county assemblies participate in the county assembly and in the community, and how they relate to male members of county assemblies. The research also examined the ideas about female members of county assemblies that are circulated in the public.

This research led to several findings. On the participation of female MCAs in the county assembly and the community, the research showed that many female MCAs must constantly juggle their political positions with demands in the community. Becoming an MCA provides new access to financial resources and political networks. It allows women to gain confidence in public speaking skills through participating in plenary sessions and training programs. These skills, financial resources, and political networks have provided incentives for some women MCAs to vie for elective seats. At the same time, becoming women MCAs increased the public demands on women. They are expected to act as financial patrons, handling requests such as paying for medical bills and school fees.

On their relations with male members of county assemblies, some female MCAs cited that male MCAs respected them, while others mentioned that male MCAs looked down on female MCAs. Women eyeing elective seats were more likely to mention that men did not respect them, owing to their desire to compete against them in forthcoming elections. However, for female MCAs with agendas that they wanted to table in the county assembly, forging good relations across gender lines enabled them to easily get the necessary support.

There are varying ideas about female MCAs that are circulated in public discourse, including that they are just the recipients of male patronage without forging their own political careers. However, the research showed that the female MCAs who wish to enter politics seek multiple sources of support, including support from friends, family, and political parties. The project also showed how female MCAs urge nongovernmental organizations to also give them monetary support, instead of just training them on leadership, branding, or political communication. They are proactive political actors, and not just mere pawns of male patronage.   

The findings of this project contribute to scholarship on political anthropology by showing the ways that money becomes necessary in enabling female politicians to build political authority. Hence, while gender quotas lead to increased women's representation, they do not necessarily change existing political cultures. The project has also contributed to the anthropology of law and bureaucracy by showing the ways in which law functions in political institutions. Members of county assemblies who could easily cite legal clauses were seen as more authoritative, and their opinion would be favored in committee meetings. The law is not always used to engineer social change, but is often interpreted by political actors to achieve their own goals. The project also contributes to feminist anthropology by showing how gender quotas become new sites for contesting women's citizenship in the nation. Politicians and the public contested often about gender quotas, with some criticizing their use in the electoral process. They also discussed the caliber of women who deserved to be in political office through gender quotas. These conversations generate deeper insights about women's positioning in the nation, showing how their access to political power has become largely influenced by the attitudes towards gender quotas.

The results from this research will also be useful in the efforts to increase women's political representation. Upon completion of the dissertation manuscript, the researcher intends to disseminate the findings of this research to political parties, government agencies, women's organizations in Kenya, as well as other county assemblies.
